title-group.article-title: Orthorhombic (NH4,Li)Eu(MoO4)2 Solid Solution: Crystal Structure and Red-Emitting Photoluminescence

abstract.p: A novel orthorhombic polymorph of (NH4,Li)­Eu­(MoO4)2 enabled by partial substitution of NH4 with Li was synthesized via a one-pot low-temperature hydrothermal route using a Li/NH4 precursor solution. Synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction and Rietveld refinement confirmed that this phase crystallizes in an orthorhombic lattice, representing a new structure type distinct from the known triclinic and tetragonal phases (P1 and I41/a space groups). Under UV excitation, the orthorhombic ((NH4)1–x Li x )­Eu­(MoO4)2 (x = 0.074–0.172) with Pbcn space group exhibits intense red photoluminescence. The emission spectrum shows multiple sharp lines from Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F J ) transitions, with a dominant peak at ∼615 nm (5D0 → 7F2) indicative of a noncentrosymmetric Eu3+ site environment. The pronounced crystal-field splitting of these emission lines further corroborates the Eu3+ site symmetry deduced from the structure. This facile hydrothermal approach demonstrates an effective strategy to stabilize previously unreported polymorphs at mild conditions, underscoring its advantage in accessing new structure–property regimes for rare-earth molybdate phosphors.

institution-wrap.institution: Japan Society for the Promotion of Science
Japan Society for the Promotion of Science
Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Lanthanide double molybdates, ARE­(MoO4)2 (A = monovalent cations; RE = trivalent rare-earth), exhibit a remarkable diversity of crystal structures and have long been studied for their luminescence arising from 4f–4f transitions of RE3+ activators. −
The framework adopted by a given ARE­(MoO4)2 depends strongly on the ionic sizes: −
for example, small cations of Li+ or Na+ favor the scheelite-type tetragonal structure with space group of I41/a, −
whereas larger cations, such as K+, Rb+ and Cs+ as well as NH4 +, destabilize the scheelite lattice, yielding lower-symmetry phases, such as triclinic, monoclinic or orthorhombic lattices. ,−
This structural versatility, coupled with the capacity to accommodate various rare-earth dopants, makes rare-earth molybdates attractive as functional materials. In particular, Eu3+-containing molybdates have drawn extensive interest as red-emitting phosphors for solid-state lighting, e.g. in white light emitting diodes (LEDs), owing to the well-known efficiency of the Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F J ) emissions. , Notably, the Eu3+ luminescence is highly sensitive to its local crystal field and thus serves as a probe of structure and site symmetry. Lowering the symmetry of the Eu3+ site (or employing a layered host lattice) tends to enhance the forced electric-dipole (ED) 5D0 → 7F2 transition by relaxing parity-forbidden selection rules and by suppressing energy migration between Eu3+ centers. These considerations underscore that judicious control of composition and structure in molybdate hosts can have a profound impact on their luminescent behavior.

Recent studies have leveraged hydrothermal synthesis to realize phase-pure AEu­(MoO4)2 compounds (A = Na, K, Rb and Cs) with tunable crystal structure and morphology. For example, a one-pot hydrothermal route without postannealing was shown to produce single-crystalline AEu­(MoO4)2 phosphors in various structural forms, alongside dramatic changes in particle shape achieved by adjusting the A/Eu ratio in the solution. , Notably, two-dimensional (2D) layered phases AEu­(MoO4)2 (A = K, Rb, Cs and NH4), synthesized via hydrothermal crystallization, exhibit remarkable resistance to concentration quenching, allowing for high levels of Eu doping. Furthermore, the distinctive two-dimensional structure of AEu­(MoO4)2 is anticipated to confer advantageous properties, including tunable luminescence characteristics through interlayer cation substitution and diverse functional properties resulting from structural modifications. By varying the alkali cation content, the particle habit of these molybdates can be morphologically engineered, for instance, RbEu­(MoO4)2 was observed to evolve from nanoplatelets to rod-like crystals to hexagonal plates, with a concomitant ∼5.8-fold increase in luminescence intensity as growth was directed within the Eu–O layered plane. In addition to morphology control, recent work has revealed polymorphism in this family. For example, KEu­(MoO4)2 is known to crystallize in multiple forms, and it has currently shown that metastable polymorphs β- and γ-KEu­(MoO4)2 can be accessed via hydrothermal synthesis, in contrast to the usual triclinic α-phase obtained by high-temperature routes. The two polymorphs of KEu­(MoO4)2 exhibit the characteristic Eu3+ red emission spectra, but with discernible differences in spectral fine structure (Stark splitting) and excitation profiles attributable to their different crystal symmetries. These advances highlight how low-temperature solution growth can stabilize new structural variants and influence photophysical properties in Eu3+-activated molybdates.

NH4Eu­(MoO4)2, one of the AEu­(MoO4)2 compounds, possesses a nonscheelite orthorhombic layered structure due to the large ionic radius of the A-site. On the other hand, LiEu­(MoO4)2 is known to adopt polymorphic structures, exhibiting tetragonal and triclinic structures analogous to those of NaEu­(MoO4)2 and KEu­(MoO4)2, , respectively, and solid-state studies have indeed reported that LiEu­(MoO4)2 shows strong Eu3+ emission under near-UV excitation. Typically, the possibility of solid solution formation is discussed based on ionic radius similarity. However, among monovalent cations, solid solution formation between Li (0.76 Å for 6-fold coordination) and NH4 (1.43 Å for 6-fold coordination), which have significantly different ionic radii, has been reported in several compounds. This is crystallographically interesting and also materially intriguing because it can induce dramatic changes in optical properties arising from geometrically significant local coordination distortions. Solid solutions of Li and NH4 ions have been synthesized in fluorides, and their function as superionic conductors, for example, has been discovered. To date, the existence and photoluminescence of orthorhombic (NH4,Li)­Eu­(MoO4)2 as a Li–NH4 solid solution remain unexplored in the literature.

In this work, we address the above knowledge gap by targeting the formation of a new NH4Eu­(MoO4)2 related molybdate under hydrothermal conditions. The purpose was to confirm the solid solution of Li within the layered structure of NH4Eu­(MoO4)2 and to evaluate its structure and luminescent properties. We have successfully obtained an orthorhombic NH4Eu­(MoO4)2 phase (space group Pbcn) with partial Li+ incorporation by a mild one-pot hydrothermal method using a mixed Li/NH4 system. The crystal structure of this new phase has been determined by Rietveld refinement, and its photoluminescence behavior (Eu3+ red emission profiles) is investigated and compared to those of conventional molybdate hosts. This study demonstrates Li solid solution formation in the NH4 analogue of LiEu­(MoO4)2, thereby advancing the understanding of rare earth molybdate crystal chemistry and provides insight into how low-symmetry structures and low-temperature synthesis can be leveraged to tune the luminescent performance of Eu3+-activated inorganic phosphors.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The following chemicals were used in the synthesis of (NH4,Li)­Eu­(MoO4)2 (NLEM) phosphor materials: (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (≥99.0%, FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chem. Co.), LiOH·H2O (≥98.0%, Kanto Chem. Co., Inc.), ammonia solution (NH3 aq.; 28.0 ∼ 30.0%, FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chem. Co.), Nitric acid (69 ∼ 70%, FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chem. Co.), Li2CO3 (≥99.0%, Kojundo Chem. Lab. Co. Ltd.), Eu2O3 (99.995%, Nippon Denko Co. Inc.) and MoO3 (>99.0%, FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chem. Co.). The europium nitrate solution was prepared by dissolving the Eu2O3 powder in an appropriate amount of nitric acid solution, followed by evaporation below 100 °C to dryness. The Eu-nitrate stock solution was diluted to 0.2 M.

sec.title: Synthesis of (NH4,Li)­Eu­(MoO4)2 Phosphors
sec.p: The general synthesis procedure is as follows: the ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate, (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (1.43 mmol), was dissolved in a small amount of distilled water, and 10 mL of 0.2 M Eu­(NO3)3 stock solution was added (Mo/Eu molar ratio = 5). Distilled water was added to make the total volume 30 mL, and the solution was stirred at room temperature for 15 min. Then, lithium hydroxide monohydrate (LiOH·H2O) as the Li ion source were added at 2, 5, and 8 mmol (Li/Eu molar ratio = 1, 2.5 and 4) and 2 mL, respectively, followed by stirring for 30 min. The total volume of the solution was adjusted to 70 mL with distilled water. The pH values of the reaction solutions were 5.5, 5.8, and 6.0 for Li/Eu ratios of 1, 2.5, and 4, respectively. After stirring, the white colloidal solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon autoclave vessel and subjected to hydrothermal reaction at 200 °C for 24 h. The resulting powder was recovered by centrifugation and washing three times with distilled water and once with ethanol, followed by filtration. The obtained product was then dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 60 °C to obtain the final product. The (NH4,Li)­Eu­(MoO4)2 samples hydrothermally synthesized at each Li/Eu ratio were labeled as NLEM-HT-xx (xx = 1, 2.5 and 4). NH4Eu­(MoO4)2 (NHEM), a comparison sample, was also synthesized by the same hydrothermal method, except that NH3 aq. was used instead of LiOH·H2O.

sec.title: Synthesis of LiEu­(MoO4)2 Phosphors by Solid-State Reaction Method
sec.p: A synthesis of the control LiEu­(MoO4)2 sample with different structures was carried out by a conventional solid-state reaction (SSR) method. The raw materials of Li2CO3, Eu2O3 and MoO3 were added in stoichiometric ratio of Li/Eu/Mo = 1:1:2 to yield 5 mmol of the target LiEu­(MoO4)2 product. These materials were then wet mixed in a mortar using acetone. The resulting mixed powder was calcined at 700 °C for 6 h under ambient atmospheric conditions to synthesize the LiEu­(MoO4)2 (LiEM-SSR) phosphor.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: The chemical states of the samples were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; PHI5600, ULVAC-PHI Inc.) using monochromatized X-rays of Al Kα (300 W). The binding energy was calibrated by the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV of the adsorbed carbon species as a reference. Thermal analyses were carried out by under ambient air with a flow rate of 200 mL/min by a thermogravimetric-differential thermal analyzer (TG-DTA; ThemoPlus TG 8120, Rigaku). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained using an FT/IR-660D-ATR instrument from JASCO Co., Japan, employing the attenuated total reflection (ATR) method. The crystal phase of the NLEM samples were determined by the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD; D2 PHASER, Bruker Co.) technique with the Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54051 Å). Particle morphology was observed by transmission electron microscope (TEM; JEM-2000EXII, JEOL Ltd., Japan) under 200 kV and a scanning electron microscope (SEM; SU6600, Hitachi High-Technologies Co., Japan) under an acceleration voltage of 15 kV. The selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) was also conducted using the TEM (JEM-2100plus, JEOL Ltd., Japan) under 200 kV. The optical absorption properties were measured by using an ultraviolet–visible–infrared (UV–vis–IR) spectrometer (V-700, JASCO Co.) with an integrated sphere attachment to obtain diffuse reflectance (DR) spectra. Photoluminescence (PL) and PL excitation (PLE) spectra were obtained by using a spectrofluorometer (FP-8500, JASCO Co.) equipped with a 150 W Xe lamp. All PL spectra were calibrated using a spectrum correction light source (ESC-142, JASCO Co.), and PLE spectra were corrected by evaluating the spectral characteristics of the Xe light source using rhodamine B dyes. The internal photoluminescence quantum yields (QYs) of the phosphor materials were also measured using the same spectrofluorometer with an optional φ100 mm integrated sphere unit for measurements. PL decay curves were collected from a digital oscilloscope (DHO924S, Rigol Tec.) with excitation source of a pulsed UV-LED at 395 nm (HQ401, Hamamatsu Quantum Co.) with 100 μs of pulse width. Temperature-dependent PL spectra were characterized utilizing a custom-designed PL measurement apparatus. Powder samples maintained under precise temperature regulation were illuminated with a 395 nm fiber LED light source. Emission signals were collected and analyzed via a fiber-coupled multichannel spectrometer (FLAME-T-OW, Ocean Insight). Throughout the thermal cycle ranging from approximately 10 to 300 °C, PL spectra were automatically acquired at sequential temperature intervals of 2.5 °C, with thermal ramping managed by a programmable temperature control system.

sec.title: Synchrotron X-ray Powder Diffraction Measurements and Structure Analysis
sec.p: Synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction (SXRD) data of the synthesized LiEM materials were measured at ambient temperature using a multiple detector system installed at the beamline BL-4B2 of the Photon Factory facility in Tsukuba, Japan. The wavelength was determined to be 1.1963(1) Å using a standard Si powder reference material (NIST SRM640c). The SXRD data with 2θ range from 8° to 150° in 0.005° step were obtained through the data reduction process. The structural refinement was performed using the Rietveld method with the orthorhombic KY­(MoO4)2 as the initial structural model and the RIETAN-FP software package. Visual representation and analysis of the refined crystal structure were facilitated using the VESTA crystallographic visualization program.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: To confirm the elemental composition of the NLEM phosphor synthesized by the hydrothermal reaction method (NLEM-HT-1), the XPS spectra were acquired as shown in Figure A,B. The binding peaks originating from the constituent elements, specifically Li, Eu, Mo, and O, were observed. The fitting analysis of the Mo 3p3/2 peak revealed that the N 1s peak was embedded within this peak region (Figure B). The relative intensity of N 1s peak compared to Mo 3p3/2 was found to be 23.4%. FT-IR analysis was performed to identify the presence of nitrogen species. Figure C shows the FT-IR spectra of the NLEM phosphor samples synthesized with different Li/Eu ratios. From the FT-IR spectra, absorption due to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the Mo–O bond was observed in the 600–1000 cm–1 region. These peaks are typical absorption observed for crystals containing MoO4 tetrahedral units. ,, On the other hand, peaks attributed to the asymmetric deformation (ν4), symmetric stretching (ν1), and asymmetric stretching vibration (ν3) of the N–H bond were observed near 1500 cm–1 and at 3042 and 3167 cm–1, respectively. , These peaks are characteristic of the ammonium ion (NH4 +), indeed suggesting the presence of NH4 + ions within the crystal. Considering the composition and structural features, the estimated chemical composition should be (NH4,Li)­Eu­(MoO4)2. The amount of the ammonium ion in the crystal lattice can be determined by thermal analysis utilizing a TG-DTA measurement. Ammonium rare-earth molybdates, NH4RE­(MoO4)2 (RE = rare earths), undergoes multistep thermal decomposition through deammoniation and dehydration condensation upon heating to form RE2Mo4O15. Therefore, if the composition is described as (NH4)1–x Li x Eu­(MoO4)2, the NH4 content (x) can be estimated using the following equation12(NH4)1−xLixEu(MoO4)2→2xLiEu(MoO4)2+2−2xEu2Mo4O15+2−2xNH3↑+1−xH2O↑

caption.p: Qualitative and quantitative analyses of NLEM-HT samples: (A) survey and (B) Mo 3p2 and N 1s narrow XPS spectra. Inset of (A) shows the enlarged profile ranging from 70 to 50 eV. (C) FT-IR spectra acquired by ATR method. Inset of (C) shows enlarged spectra of N–H peaks at ca. 3042 and 3167 cm–1. (D) TG curve of heating process (10 °C/min under ambient air). Inset of (D) shows the NH4 contents of NLEM-HT samples with different Li/Eu ratio estimated from TG analysis.

sec.p: TG curve of the synthesized NLEM with Li/Eu = 4 (NLEM-HT-4) is shown in Figure D. The thermal decomposition behavior of NLEM was observed to consist of three characteristic weight loss steps. In the first step, a small weight loss of −0.456% in the temperature region of ∼150 °C is attributed to the drying of surface-adsorbed water molecules and does not involve crystal desorption. The second step is a significant weight loss (−3.28%) in the region of 300–400 °C, which corresponds to deammoniation. The third step shows a weight loss of −0.980% in the temperature range of 450–500 °C, attributed to dehydration condensation. The estimated ammonium contents of all the samples, based on their weight loss behavior, are summarized in the inset of Figure D. In related prior research, it is reported that amorphization occurs at 400 °C, and in this study with Li introduction, similar amorphization likely occurs in the second step. As the Li/Eu ratio was increased (as the ammonium component in the starting solution becomes relatively less abundant), the NH4 + content in the product increased. This trend is presumed to result primarily from the enhanced incorporation of NH4 + ions, driven by the increase in pH value, likely due to the higher pH of the solution favoring NH4 + incorporation into the lattice (rather than remaining in solution as NH3).

The LiEu­(MoO4)2 has been well-known to crystallize in a triclinic system (space group P1) and a tetragonal scheelite-type structure with a space group of I41/a (No. 88). To date, these are the only two crystal structures known for this compound. Triclinic LiEu­(MoO4)2 phase is prepared by a solid-state reaction at temperatures of approximately 800 °C or below, , while tetragonal LiEu­(MoO4)2 phase is crystallized from the molten state at ca. 940 °C. Although comprehensive thermodynamic relationships have not been clarified, it is assumed that the possibility of adopting a tetragonal structure near the melting point has been suggested. However, no reports exist on their synthesis through aqueous solution processes. In contrast, NH4Eu­(MoO4)2 is known to adopt an orthorhombic Pbcn structure. However, structural information on the solid solutions synthesized in this study has not been reported to date. Therefore, we conducted a crystal structure analysis using synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XRD). Figure A shows the Rietveld refinement results of the synchrotron XRD profiles for NLEM-HT-4. The obtained XRD patterns revealed that NLEM phosphors synthesized via hydrothermal processing exhibit an orthorhombic Pbcn structure. As summarized in Table , the reliability factors R wp and S were 12.253% and 0.9305, respectively, indicating that the refinement yielded reliable and satisfactory results. Table summarizes the refined atomic parameters, and the corresponding crystal structure is illustrated in Figure B,C (rendered with VESTA software). This structure is a layered compound in which EuO8 polyhedral units and MoO4 tetrahedral units share edges to form [Eu­(MoO4)2]− anionic layers in the ac plane, with Li+ or NH4 + ions intercalated between the layers along the c-axis. In the series of NH4Ln­(MoO4)2 compounds with various rare-earth elements, light rare-earth ions (Ln = La–Gd) adopt an orthorhombic Pbcn (No. 60) space group, while heavy rare-earth ions (Ln = Tb–Lu and Y) crystallize in a monoclinic P2/c (no. 13) system. Although all exhibit similar layered structures, the symmetry differs depending on the ionic radius. The lattice volume of the obtained NLEM-HT-4 sample was V = 793.71(2) Å3, which is slightly larger than that of the reported NH4Gd­(MoO4)2 (V = 792.3(1) Å3), generally consistent with the Vegard’s law behavior observed in ammonium salts. Structural refinement by Rietveld analysis using synchrotron XRD profile was also performed for NLEM synthesized by the SSR method, and the results were found to be in good agreement with the previously well-known triclinic structure of LiEu­(MoO4)2 (Figure S1 and Table S1).

caption.p: (A) Results of Rietveld analysis of the NLEM-HT-4 sample using the SXRD profile measured at room temperature. (B) Crystal structure and (C) atomic coordination connections of the orthorhombic (NH4,Li)­Eu­(MoO4)2 refined by Rietveld analysis.

caption.title: Lattice Parameters and R-Factors for NLEM-HT-4 Obtained from the Rietveld Refinement of the SXRD Data at Room Temperature
Atomic Parameters of NLEM-HT-4 Obtained from the Rietveld Refinement of the SXRD Data at Room Temperature

fn.label: b
fn.p: Site occupancy of Li/N was fixed to the value estimated from TG analysis.

fn.label: c
fn.p: The B iso values were constrained to be 1.

sec.p: Figure A shows the XRD patterns of the NLEM-HT samples synthesized with various Li/Eu ratios. All samples exhibit similar diffraction profiles, and no impurity phases other than those corresponding to the orthorhombic structure are observed. Furthermore, no obvious shifts in the peak positions are detected, which is generally consistent with the results of thermogravimetric analysis. Compared to the XRD pattern of NH4Eu­(MoO4)2 (NHEM), a nonsolid solution with orthorhombic structure, a shift of the diffraction peak position to the higher angle was observed for both NLEMs (Figure S2), which is reasonable for the introduction of Li into the lattice. Indeed, the b-axis length in the stacking direction decreases as the Li solid solution amount increases (Figure S2C). In layered AEu­(MoO4)2 compounds (A = K–Cs), it has been reported that the particle morphology transforms from plate-like to rod-like as the A/Eu ratio is varied. This morphological change is attributed to the balance between nucleation and crystal growth rates, influenced by the solution pH. Therefore, unique morphological changes can be expected in LiEu­(MoO4)2. Figure B shows SEM and TEM images of the samples. Rhombic plate-like particles were observed across all Li/Eu ratios, with thinner plate-like morphologies particularly evident at higher Li/Eu ratios. In addition, particle size tends to increase as the Li/Eu ratio decreases, i.e. with decreasing Li concentration. This trend is consistent with that observed in AEu­(MoO4)2 (A = K–Cs) systems. On the other hand, the particle morphology of LiEM_SSR yielded rough particles of about 1 μm characteristic of high-temperature solid-state reactions, while that of NHEM was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis, resulting in plate-like crystals very similar to NLEM_HT particles (Figure S3).

caption.p: (A) XRD analysis of NLEM-HT phosphors synthesized with different Li/Eu ratio. (B) Particle morphologies observed by (top) SEM, (middle) TEM images and (bottom) SAED patterns of NLEM-HT phosphors synthesized with different Li/Eu ratio.

sec.p:
The optical absorption properties of NLEM-HT were analyzed by UV–vis–NIR spectroscopy, and the resulting diffuse reflectance (DR) spectra are shown in Figure A. The optical absorption features of NLEM-HT consist primarily of two components: a broad absorption band around ∼350 nm, attributed to charge transfer (CT) transitions from O2– to Mo6+ and Eu3+, and sharp line-like absorption bands observed in the 350–600 nm range, corresponding to intra4f transitions of Eu3+. , The spectra of the samples with Li/Eu = 2.5 and 4 show almost no difference; however, a light shift in the absorption edge is observed when compared to the sample with Li/Eu = 1. The estimated bandgap energies are 4.00 eV for Li/Eu = 2.5 and 4, and 3.94 eV for Li/Eu = 1, respectively. This small difference is likely attributable to the variation in Li/NH4 ratio. The photoluminescence (PL) and photoluminescence excitation (PLE) spectra are shown in Figure B,C, respectively. The PLE spectrum corresponding to the 614 nm PL peak exhibits two distinct excitation processes, similar to the DR spectrum: one is a broad band due to charge transfer (CT) transitions from O2– to Mo6+ and Eu3+, and the other consists of sharp peaks arising from the intra4f transitions of Eu3+. Although many Eu3+-doped molybdate phosphors have been reported, the energy of their charge transfer transitions varies widely, which is from the deep UV to the near-UV region, depending on the host structure. In particular, host lattices featuring MoO x with higher coordination numbers, such as trigonal bipyramidal MoO5 and octahedral MoO6 units, tend to exhibit lower CT excitation energies due to increased orbital overlap between coordinating ions, allowing excitation under near-UV light. −
In contrast, as confirmed by the structural analysis, orthorhombic NLEM-HT consists of MoO4 tetrahedra, and thus exhibits higher CT excitation energies, with the corresponding CT band located in the shorter wavelength region. In all reported AEu­(MoO4)2 structures (A = alkali metals), the Mo ions are coordinated as tetrahedra, and their CT excitation bands consistently appear around 300 nm. ,, In addition, sharp excitation peaks attributed to the 4f–4f transitions of Eu3+ are observed beyond 350 nm, as shown in detail in Figure S4. These are characteristic features of typical Eu3+-activated phosphors and are also observed in compounds with similar structures, such as KRE­(MoO4)2:Eu3+ (RE = Gd, Y and Lu) ,, and AEu­(MoO4)2 (A = K–Cs). Figure C shows the PL spectra measured under excitation at 395 nm, corresponding to the 7F0 → 5L6 transition of Eu3+ ion. Sharp emission lines originating from the 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1–6) transitions of Eu3+ ion are observed. Among them, the 5D0 → 7F2 electric dipole transition exhibits a particularly strong emission peak, whereas the 5D0 → 7F1 magnetic dipole (MD) transition is extremely weak. The 5D0 → 7F1 transition is generally insensitive to the local site symmetry of Eu3+, while the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is highly dependent on it. In noncentrosymmetric sites, the crystal field allows mixing of the 4f orbitals of rare-earth ions with 5d orbitals, which partially relaxes the parity-forbidden nature of electric dipole transitions, resulting in enhanced emission. In the orthorhombic NLEM-HT phosphors with the space group of Pbcn, Eu3+ ion occupies the 4c site, which has site symmetry “2”. (Hermann–Mauguin notation; H–M notation), indicating the absence of an inversion center. This explains the pronounced intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 electric dipole transition in the PL spectrum. The small satellite peaks observed for each transition are attributed to Stark splitting. Among the samples synthesized with different Li/Eu ratios, those with Li/Eu = 2.5 and 4 exhibit nearly identical emission intensities, while the sample with Li/Eu = 1 shows a significantly reduced intensity, which is only about 20% of the others (inset of Figure C). This decrease in PL intensity is correlated with the Li+ occupancy of the A sites; the NLEM-HT-1 sample with the highest Li+ content has the weakest PL intensity. As TG analysis indicates that Li+ occupies ca. 18% of the A sites in NLEM-HT-1, significant local distortion likely occurs and may account for the observed PL decrease. Nevertheless, comparing the PL intensities of NHEM with those of NLEM-HT-2.5 and NLEM-HT-4 (Figure S5), the PL intensities of NLEM-HT-2.5 and NLEM-HT-4 are higher. The internal quantum yield (IQY) of the obtained NLEM-HT phosphors was estimated to be 0.288 for NLEM-HT-4, 0.373 for NLEM-HT-2.5, and 0.0270 for NLEM-HT-1, respectively (Figure S6). Figure D shows the PL decay curves of the NLEM-HT samples in the 620 ± 5 nm range, measured under 100 μs pulsed excitation at 395 nm using an LED source. For all samples, the obtained decay curves are well fitted by a single-exponential function. The decay behavior was modeled using a single exponential decay function 2I(t)=A+Bexp(−t/τ)where I(t) is the PL intensity at time t, A is the background, B is the amplitude, and τ is the PL lifetime of Eu3+. The lifetimes estimated from the fitted decay curves were 0.6057(8) ms for NLEM-HT-4, 0.6200(7) ms for NLEM-HT-2.5, and 0.1016(5) ms for NLEM-HT-1, respectively. A significant shortening of the PL lifetime was observed for the sample with Li/Eu = 1. Considering that PL efficiency is generally proportional to PL lifetime, these results are consistent with the measured internal quantum yields.

caption.p: Optical absorption and photoluminescence properties of NLEM-HT phosphors: (A) DR spectra (inset shows Tauc plots), (B) PLE spectra monitored at 614 nm emission, PL spectra measured under excitation at 395 nm (inset shows plot of the relative integrated PL intensity), and (D) PL decay curves in the 620 ± 5 nm range excited under 100 μs pulsed excitation at 395 nm.

sec.p:
As described above, the NLEM-HT phosphors synthesized in this study exhibit stabilization of the orthorhombic phase through the incorporation of ammonium ions, resulting in a crystal structure distinct from the previously well-known triclinic phase. Figure shows the PL spectra under 395 nm excitation for three different samples of the orthorhombic NLEM-HT-4, the triclinic LiEM-SSR and NHEM-HT samples. While the PL spectrum of NLEM-HT-4 is consistent with the description given earlier, the 5D0 → 7F2 transition in LiEM-SSR is clearly split into two components. This splitting can be attributed to Stark splitting of Eu3+ ions located in a site with lower symmetry, as expected for the P1 space group. To further quantify the local symmetry of the Eu3+ sites, an evaluation based on the Judd–Ofelt (J–O) theory was considered. The J–O analysis of the emission spectrum provides valuable insights into the local structure and bonding environment around the rare-earth ions, , and its theory can also provide a framework for calculating the spontaneous emission rate A R from the initial excited state |Ψ′J′ > to the final state |ΨJ>, as expressed in the following equation ,
3AR(ΨJ,Ψ′J′)=64π4ν̃33h(2J+1)[n(n2+2)29DED+n3DMD]In this expression, ν̃ denotes the centroid wavenumber (cm–1), h represents Planck’s constant (=6.63 × 10–27 erg s–1), 2J + 1 corresponds to the degeneracy of the initial state (unity for 5D0). The term n refers to the refractive index of the host matrix. Given that LNEM represents a newly synthesized compound in this investigation, its refractive index remains undetermined. Additionally, refractive index values for the previously reported triclinic phases LiEu­(MoO4)2 and NH4Eu­(MoO4)2 are unavailable in the literature. Consequently, we employed the refractive index of the structurally analogous LiGd­(MoO4)2 (n = 1.95) as an approximation. The terms D ED and D MD denote the electric and magnetic dipole transition strengths (expressed in esu2cm), respectively. Magnetic dipole transitions in lanthanide ions exhibit minimal sensitivity to the local crystal field environment, enabling reliable theoretical predictions (D MD = 9.6 × 10–42 esu2 cm2). The oscillator strengths of all forced electric dipole transitions (both absorptive and emissive) for a lanthanide ion within a specific host matrix can be determined using merely three phenomenological parameters Ωλ through the relationship 4DED=e2∑λ=2,4,6Ωλ|⟨ΨJ∥Uλ∥Ψ′J′⟩|2Here, e denotes the elementary charge (=4.803 × 10–10 esu), while Ωλ (λ = 2,4,6 for Eu3+) constitute the Judd–Ofelt intensity parameters. The squared reduced matrix elements (RMEs) |⟨ΨJ∥Uλ∥Ψ′J′⟩|2 are transition-specific quantities (these values are summarized in Table S2). These relationships indicate that each J–O parameter Ωλ depends solely on the square of a single reduced matrix element corresponding to the electric dipole 5D0 → 7F J (J = 2, 4, 6) transitions. This distinctive property enables the extraction of J–O parameters directly from PL spectra. Accordingly, the experimental value of Ωλ can be obtained by calculating the ratio of the integrated intensity ∫I
J dν of the 5D0 → 7F J (J = 2, 4, 6) transitions to the integrated intensity ∫I md dν of the 5D0 → 7F1 transition ,
5Ωλ=DMDν̃md3e2ν̃J3|⟨ΨJ∥Uλ∥Ψ′J′⟩|29n3n(n2+2)2∫IJdν∫ImddνIn this equation, ν̃md and ν̃J represent the centroid wavenumbers (cm–1) corresponding to the 5D0 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F J (J = 2, 4, 6) transitions, respectively. By combining eqs and , the radiative decay rates A R(md) and A R(ed) for MD and ED processes can be derived as shown in the following expressions6AR(md)=n3AR(md)′=64π4ν̃33h(2J+1)n3Smd 7AR(ed)=64π4ν̃33h(2J+1)n(n2+2)29e2∑λ=2,4,6Ωλ|⟨ΨJ∥Uλ∥Ψ′J′⟩|2

caption.p: Normalized PL spectra of LiEM-SSR, NLEM-HT and NHEM-HT phosphors. Insets show the enlarged views of 5D0 → 7F J with J = 1 and 6.

sec.p: It should be noted that the magnetic dipole emission rate A R(md) for the 5D0 → 7F1 transition of Eu3+ in a medium scale with the corresponding vacuum value (A R(md) ′). The Judd–Ofelt analysis was conducted using integrated PL intensities of NLEM and its related phosphors (LiEM-SSR and NHEM-HT) derived from the PL spectra (Figure ), with the calculated parameters presented in Table . LiEM-SSR crystallizes in the P1 space group, where Eu3+ occupies the 2i site. This site symmetry is denoted as “1” in the H-M notation, indicating the absence of any symmetry elements. In contrast, in NLEM-HT and NHEM-HT, the Eu3+ ion occupies a site with site symmetry “2”, which lacks an inversion center but possesses a 2-fold rotational axis along the b-axis. Therefore, NLEM-HT is expected to exhibit lower local symmetry than LiEM-SSR. The Ω2 parameter is known to strongly correlate with the asymmetry of the coordination polyhedron. Based on this relationship, LiEM-SSR exhibits Ω2 = 19.1 × 10–20 cm2, while NLEM-HT shows a slightly lower value of Ω2 = 16.9 × 10–20 cm2, supporting the interpretation that NLEM-HT possesses slightly higher symmetry. Furthermore, when compared with NHEM-HT, which possesses the same space group (symmetry), NHEM-HT exhibits Ω2 = 16.2 × 10–20 cm2, indicating that NLEM-HT shows a slightly higher value. This suggests that the introduction of Li leads to a reduction in lo cal symmetry. In contrast, the Ω6 value of NLEM-HT was significantly larger than that of LiEM-SSR. Although the interpretation of the Ω4 and Ω6 parameters remains under discussion, several studies have suggested that these parameters are influenced by multiple factors in ionic crystals, such as the degree of covalency between Eu3+ and ligand bonding, 6s electron density, ligand field distortion, and the basicity of the surrounding environment. ,

caption.title: Calculated Judd–Ofelt Intensity Parameters, Ω J (J = 2, 4, 6), and Radiative Transition Probabilities, A R, of Transitions of 5D0 → 7F J (J = 2, 4, 6) of Eu3+ for NLEM-HT and LiEM-SSR and NHEM-HT Phosphors

fn.label: a
fn.p: Atomic ratio of Li and NH4 is estimated from TG analysis.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Site symmetry represented as H-M notation.

sec.p: Figure A,B show the temperature dependence of the PL spectra under 395 nm excitation. Both phosphors exhibit negligible changes in PL intensity up to approximately 373 K, beyond which a sharp decrease in intensity is observed. At 573 K, the luminescence is almost completely quenched. However, in the temperature range of 473–523 K, a difference in the t hermal quenching behavior is observed between NLEM-HT-4 and LiEM-SSR; the decay in NLEM- HT-4 appears to be more gradual. This thermally induced luminescence quenching behavior can be analyzed in terms of the thermal activation energy (ΔE), which can be estimated using the following equation 8I(T)=I01+Γ0/Γνexp(−ΔEkT)

caption.p: Temperature dependences on the PL spectra under 395 nm excitation of the (top) NLEM-HT-4 and (bottom) LiEM-SSR phosphors. Insets show the temperature dependency of relative PL peak intensity of 5D0 → 7F2 transition of Eu3+.

sec.p: The I 0 and I(T) denote the PL intensities at the initial temperature and at a given temperature, respectively. The Γν represents the radiative rate, Γ0 is the attempt rate of the nonradiative process, k is the Boltzmann constant, and T is the absolute temperature. From the temperature-dependent PL curves, the activation energies (ΔE) for NLEM-HT-4 and LiEM-SSR were estimated to be 0.455(3) eV and 0.471(7) eV, respectively, suggesting that LiEM-SSR with triclinic structure exhibits slightly higher thermal stability. Although the orthorhombic phase (NLEM-HT) exhibits a slow decay in the moderate temperature range, the overall thermal quench activation energy is slightly higher for the triclinic phase (LiEM-SSR), suggesting a slightly higher final quench onset temperature. To further elucidate the relationship between photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) and PL lifetime, temperature-dependent PL decay measurements were performed on LNEM-HT-1, LNEM-HT-4, LiEM-SSR, and NHEM-SSR in the range from room temperature to 300 °C (Figures C and S7). Remarkably, the PL lifetime of LiEM-HT-1 remained nearly constant over the entire temperature range, suggesting that Eu3+ ions in this sample occupy highly distorted sites. The enhanced asymmetry of these sites promotes electric dipole (ED) transitions, increasing the spontaneous emission rate and rendering the lifetime less sensitive to thermally activated nonradiative processes. In contrast, LNEM-HT-4, LiEM-SSR, and NHEM-SSR exhibited a clear decrease in PL lifetime beginning at approximately 100 °C, consistent with the onset of thermal quenching observed in PL intensity (Figure A,B). The reduced site distortion in these samples leads to a lower ED transition probability and hence a smaller radiative decay rate, making the PL lifetime more susceptible to nonradiative decay pathways activated at elevated temperatures. These findings highlight the critical role of local site symmetry in governing the balance between radiative and nonradiative processes in ((NH4)1–x Li x )­Eu­(MoO4)2 phosphors and provide further support for the interpretation that the short PL lifetime observed in LNEM-HT-1 is primarily due to the increased radiative rate arising from site asymmetry.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized a lithium substituted ammonium europium molybdate, (NH4,Li)­Eu­(MoO4)2, via a hydrothermal route and identified it as a new orthorhombic phase (space group Pbcn). This phase is a previously unreported europium double molybdate in which NH4 is partially replaced by lithium. Rietveld refinement of synchrotron X-ray diffraction data confirmed the formation of a single-phase solid solution with an orthorhombic framework analogous to that of NH4Eu­(MoO4)2, indicating that the mixed-cation composition is accommodated without disrupting the crystal structure. The as-prepared crystals exhibit well-defined morphologies that evolve from rhombic plate-like to thinner plate-like as the Li+/NH4 + ratio is varied, reflecting the influence of growth conditions on crystal habit. Photoluminescence measurements reveal the characteristic Eu3+ red emissions dominated by the 614 nm 5D0 → 7F2 transition, confirming that Eu3+ remains an optically active center in the orthorhombic lattice. The luminescence intensity is moderately affected by the mixed Li+/NH4 + occupancy, slight quenching is observed due to local structural distortions, yet the material maintains strong emission overall. Judd-Ofelt analysis revealed that the novel orthorhombic-type (NH4,Li)­Eu­(MoO4)2 exhibits characteristic strong electric dipole transitions originating from the asymmetry of the Eu3+ sites. Additionally, the thermal stability of the luminescence was found to be comparable to that of the previously reported triclinic phase LiEu­(MoO4)2. This work thus provides novel insights regarding Li solid solution behavior in rare earth molybdate crystal chemistry and demonstrates how deliberate cation substitution can tailor the structure and optical properties of Eu3+-doped inorganic phosphors.

ack.p: This work was supported by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Numbers 22K05264 and 20H00297, and Feasibility Study for Young Researchers (FS) in “Crossover Alliance to Create the Future with People, Intelligence and Materials” from MEXT, Japan. Synchrotron powder XRD measurements were performed with the BL-4B2 at the Photon Factory (PF) with the approval of the High Energy Accelerator Research Organization (KEK) (Proposal No. 2023P003).

notes.p:
The Supporting Information is available free of charge at https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.inorgchem.5c02616.
